subject: Add boot order configuration support for yosemitev2.
commitMessage:
Add boot order configuration support for yosemitev2.

Added implementation for boot order configuration
to get and set boot order using dbus objects in multihost.

TESTED: Tested in tiogapass and yosemitev2 hardware.

Signed-off-by: Jayashree Dhanapal <jayashree-d@hcl.com>
Change-Id: Iae9da2e36ac78c23e53bf2d1161e23c975384950

Patch Set 29: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged by Patrick Williams
I don't know why this is called 'oneTimePath' because it isn't always that.
Ack
Why is this capitalized?
I will update this.

Thank you for moving the configuration to the 'settings' service.  I much prefer that implementation rather than this IPMI-specific file.

Why do we still need the code from line 625-633?  Can't we just store entirely in the settings service now rather than using this OEM file for this data?
We can set/get Boot Mode and Boot Source in settings service, but remaining boot order cannot be stored in dbus objects, so we are storing those boot order in oemData.

Why can't "remaining boot order" be stored in dbus objects?  Is this a problem where the dbus object hasn't been properly defined?  Can't we make proposals to get this cleaned up then?  I'd like to not have this magic OEM file because it means you cannot use Redfish to configure it (for example).

From my understanding, there is limitation in dbus-interfaces, so I have updated 2 data values. If there is dbus-interfaces available, we can add it in there. Please provide your suggestions on this.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/tree/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/Boot
If we have functionality that isn't covered by dbus-interfaces, we should be proposing enhancements to cover our functionality.
Sure, posted this issue in mailing lists, and also working on this.
Why are you using string comparison for a number?
I will update this.

Don't you need to confirm that hostIdx < INSTANCES?

Do we even need INSTANCES to be an integer?  Can we use the same OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES variable we use elsewhere?

Yes, I will add the condition to confirm the INSTANCES.
OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES is passed as arguments in Cmakelists from bb file.
Why is this capitalized?
Ack

I'm having trouble reading this code, but I think you're resetting the "one-time" setting?  Two suggestions:

- Please move to the end after setBootOrder because if setBootOrder is unsuccessful we don't want to clear the one-time.

- Please check the logic because I don't think it is correct.  My reading is that the logic is currently "if one time is not enabled, set one time enabled for *next* call" but I think it should be "if one time *is* enabled, clear it".
Sure, I will update this.
Why look in the 'oemData' anymore?
We can set/get Boot Mode and Boot Source in settings service, but remaining boot order cannot be stored in dbus objects, so we are storing those boot order in oemData.
Why were these removed from the 'PrintAndRegister' calls above?
I changed PrintAndRegister to new registerhandler to manage the optional parameter like hostIdx to get the host option.

I really don't think we should use "number of hosts" here.  The OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES is set up so that someone could do "1 3 5" on a system.  We would need INSTANCES=5?

Also the "INSTANCES=0" is similarly awkward because there is 1 instance but it is just named "instance 0".
Sure, I will update this.

"max host?"

Isn't INSTANCES a #define created by cmake in a header file?  If it is a #define it can be passed as a literal integer and remove the string-conversion.

I'm not sure we should have an INSTANCES configuration like this anyhow though.
I will update this.
Same comments here.
Ack

I'm still confused on what is going on here.  OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES is a string with multiple entries.  How are we going to turn this into a single number?  How do you confirm that all of the hostIdx are valid in the string?
I am working on this, I will update this in next patchset.

Why aren't you just initializing 'defaultVal' to the array?  The copy seems like wasted effort.

If you do need a copy, use a std::algorithm and not your own for-loop.
I have removed the map, since bootval is similar for all the key.

This code also seems... odd.  Why are you making a map of identical elements (all defaultVal) only to pick it back apart with a find based on the host id?

What if bootVal.find(num) returns nothing?

I have removed the map, since bootval is similar for all the key.
If the INSTANCES is not present it will return -1. Therefore, the condition will not satisfied in get/set boot order func and it will show "Invalid command".

This is doing C-string comparison, which will never be true.

I don't think this is correct for the case where you're handling a single-host system (like Tiogapass) anyhow because the single instance should be 0, right?

If OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES is not present, then it will assign INSTANCES to 1 and "/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot" objpath will be used.

Based on your below comment, INSTANCES was changed to 1, since single host system will have 1 INSTANCES.
Please confirm the INSTANCES value for single host system.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/fb-ipmi-oem/+/38614/18/CMakeLists.txt#79

Sorry if what I was asking in that earlier comment was unclear. Previously you had an INSTANCES variable, which was a count. Now it is a list of present hosts. 

For single host systems, the instance id is 0.
For multi host systems, the instance ids start at 1.
To be clear, this should be a 0 now since you are not using INSTANCES as a count, but as a list of valid host ids.
Done
Please use 'size_t' for things which are sizes or countable.
Done
Thanks for your suggestion, I will update this.
Use size_t or auto.  You're doing a type conversion since vector::size returns a size_t already.
Done
std::copy(std::begin(data), std::end(data), bootSeq);
Done
auto or size_t.
Done
Why do we have this special case?  Why do the call to 'findHost' if we are in the single-host configuration?
I updated in the latest code, please verify it.

With your current implementation, you cannot have this condition.
The proposal I made throws instead on error.  You might need to change this to a catch.  Alternatively you could use a std::optional return from your findHost function (instead of throwing).
Thanks for your suggestion, I updated in the code. Please verify it.
Can we use the 'host_name' as the key into the 'oemData' cache in setBootOrder instead of making a new string?
Done
If you are not going to use `host_name` again in this function, suggest using 'std::move(host_name)'.
Done
Please avoid duplicating this code if you can.
Done
Why is there a global variable now?  I think you intended this to be inside findHost function?
It is removed in updated patchset.
This works ok.  I don't particularly like stringstream because it isn't especially efficient.  It would be better to have used 'find' and 'substr' on the original string to create the segments.
Done

One of the comments I made before is that this should be a 'static const vector<string>' created by calling a function.  The issue here is that you're having to rebuild the string and split it out each time this function is called.
Done

The function returns 'size_t' which is unsigned.  

I would rather not use return-code patterns but throw an exception for an exceptional case (or use std::optional).  I've mentioned this on an earlier review at the place this function is called:

> With your current implementation, you cannot have this condition.
> The proposal I made throws instead on error.  You might need to change this to a catch.  Alternatively you could use a std::optional return from your findHost function (instead of throwing).
Sorry for making delay, now I think I understood this part and updated the patchset with std::optional. Please review it.

Please do not use global variables for these.  Return them from the function (or pass l-value references into the function as output parameters).  You could have the function return a 'std::tuple<size_t, string, string>'.
Done

std::make_tuple(std::move(bootObjPath), std::move(hostName))

1. Why doesn't make_tuple need 'std::'?  Seems someone polluted the namespace with a 'using namespace std;'?

2. Add 'std::move' to the strings because you are done with them at the point you are 'moving' them into the tuple.

I missed std::make_tuple while updating, Thanks for pointing it out.
Updated the patchset with std::move.
Done
Also use construct in place here.
Done
